> Static class is different from singleton. For example, sometimes we need to test different kvstore implementations, and it's difficult to do it with static class.

If we implement kvstore as a singleton, isn't it also hard to test different implementations? I think I'm missing something here, I would appreciated it if you could give some example.
> And I think static methods do not have external linkage,

They do have external linkage, since the `static` keyword do not presents when we "define" the methods.
> which is the main issue you want to solve in this pull request

The main issue I want to solve is, currently, when user `#include "MxNetCpp.h"` in several .cpp files, the "definition" of those class methods and global variables which defined in .hpp will be repeatedly included in .o files. And since c++ only allow each function or object have "one definition", these duplicate definition will cause error when we link .o files together. The solution is to add `inline` keyword to allow same definition appears in different translation unit, otherwise user can never include mxnet.cpp in more than one .cpp file.

I installed mxnet today on Ubuntu Linux, and after running into frustratingly bad performance on a simple linear regression problem (which appeared to be solvable in `neuralnet`/`nnet`), I discovered the advice in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/4287 to use rmsprop... which crashes:

```
R> mxModel1 <- mx.model.FeedForward.create(lro1, X=train.x, y=train.y,
+                                         eval.data=list(data=test.x, label=test.y),
+                                         ctx=mx.cpu(), num.round=nRound,
+                                         array.batch.size=batchSize,
+                                         eval.metric=mx.metric.rmse,
+                                         verbose=verbose,
+                                         array.layout=array.layout,
+                                         optimizer=optimizer
+                                         )
Error in mx.nd.sqrt(n - g * g + 1e-04) : 
  ./base.h:291: Unsupported parameter type object type for argument data, expect integer, logical, or string.
Calls: mx.model.FeedForward.create ... <Anonymous> -> lapply -> FUN -> update -> mx.nd.sqrt
```

As does jeremiedb's simple `nd.sqrt` example with the same `base.h`-related error. (Note: it does run if I switch to "sgd" as the optimizer and set a `learning.rate` as well, so my installation is otherwise working.)
Yes, I meant `X.reshape((3, 8))` , updated the question. The `-3` flag doesn't work either. I actually mean to reshape without swaping the axes.

Can you try this after pulling the latest code from the repo?

Create the pool sym as this:
```python
pool1 = mx.sym.Pooling(conv1, kernel=(1,2,2), stride=(1,2,2), pool_type="max", cudnn_off=True)
```
This will turn off cudnn 3D pooling and use MXNet pooling operator instead. Check whether the results are expected and we can go from there.

Another problem I have is that the current code is written for MKL (it uses the C LAPACK interface in MKL), it fails all online Travis tests. What would you suggest doing? Shall I write for ATLAS/OpenBLAS as well? The problem is the C LAPACK interface in these libs all differ a bit; and I'll have to modify the `Makefile` to export environment variables signalling the current LAPACK lib.
@zhenlinluo @glingyan

You can try
```python
b = mx.sym.Pooling(data = a, pool_type = 'max', kernel = (1, k), stride = (1, 1), cudnn_off=True, name = 'pool')
```
This will force using MXNet Pooling operator, instead of cuDNNPooling.

In addition, it seems you are just doing 1-D pooling. You can pass 1-D shapes to the Pooling operator which runs faster than the 2-D version.

> tensorboard==1.0.0a6

I added/changed this to common/fit.py in image classification to get a dummy test running.
(FYI there is an error in the doc string for LogMetricsCallback, mx.tensorboard should be mx.contrib.tensorboard. [lines](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/contrib/tensorboard.py#L31-L32))

```
    # starting around line 170 in image_classification/common/fit.py
    evaluation_log = 'logs/eval'
    training_log = 'logs/train'
    eval_end_callbacks = [mx.contrib.tensorboard.LogMetricsCallback(evaluation_log)]
    batch_end_callbacks += [mx.contrib.tensorboard.LogMetricsCallback(training_log)]
    # run
    model.fit(train,
        begin_epoch        = args.load_epoch if args.load_epoch else 0,
        num_epoch          = args.num_epochs,
        eval_data          = val,
        eval_metric        = eval_metrics,
        kvstore            = kv,
        optimizer          = args.optimizer,
        optimizer_params   = optimizer_params,
        initializer        = initializer,
        arg_params         = arg_params,
        aux_params         = aux_params,
        batch_end_callback = batch_end_callbacks, # This was updated
        eval_end_callback  = eval_end_callbacks, # This was added
        epoch_end_callback = checkpoint,
        allow_missing      = True,
        monitor            = monitor)
```

@jmerkow thanks for your feedback! 

To clarify, did you use `tensorboard --logdir=logs/train` or `tensorboard --logdir=logs/`? As I know, if we use `tensorboard --logdir=logs/`, it should be two different colors in the graph.

You can use `prefix` in `LogMetricsCallback` to plot train&eval metrics in separate graph:

```python
eval_end_callbacks = [mx.contrib.tensorboard.LogMetricsCallback(evaluation_log, prefix='eval')]
batch_end_callbacks += [mx.contrib.tensorboard.LogMetricsCallback(training_log, prefix='train')]
```

Or they would be in one graph just like your case, in this case, we have to use relative mode rather than step mode. Any suggestions are welcomed and let's make it better.

I used logs/.  It just never got to the eval call back, I killed it before it finished.  I am just testing the tensorboard to use to train on my data.
I solved it in my branch by adding the step manually, i.e. 
`self.summary_writer.add_scalar(name, value)` 
to 
`self.summary_writer.add_scalar(name, value, global_step=param.nbatch)`.

So it turns out the problem comes from the fact that, by default, the first argument is the deprecated `target_shape` while it should be `shape` to be compatible with NumPy and the doc. Would also be more intuitive for users, in particular those coming from NumPy.

> For static methods, I'm not sure if they will create multiple definitions in serverl source files. If they don't, then there is no problem.

Although these static methods create multiple definitions in several source files, they are `inline`, so more than one definition in the entire program is fine.

Creating an operator from an operator seems weird. If you have access to the forward operator why not just use it for the backward operation.

You can cache the operator used in imperativeinvoke (instead of deleting it) and reuse in backward. I don't see why you need another interface.

OK, it seems that this situation happens because mxnet contains C extension, and PyCharm only handles ordinary python code.

One possible work round is using the terminal panel in PyCharm. Run ipython in that panel, import mxnet as mx, then

    mx.sym.FullyConnected?

shows the full comment string, and 

    mx.sym.FullyConnected?

shows source code the the function
@piiswrong This PR LGTM. Can you help merge it? Thank you!

@piiswrong 
Eric, I removed the CustomStructInfo defines from the swig templates that caused test failures 
for https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5589
Perl api currently does not support custom ops so these definitions had no business to be there in the first place.
Thanks.
Hmm, seems like an user error. I did a system update and it broke CUDA compatibility. Didn't realize for a bit of time it apparently...

>If you have access to the forward operator why not just use it for the backward operation.

This part is what the second logic does.

> You can cache the operator used in imperativeinvoke (instead of deleting it) and reuse in backward. I don't see why you need another interface.

If the operator is invoked through imperative calls, you can do this. But this does not solve the inherent problem that forward and backward are coupled. This blocks many passes from developed. For example, if its forward operator is optimized away (fused or whatever), its backward operator must be changed as well, but this may not be possible. The stateful operator is hard to deal with and marking some of them to be stateless can solve most of the problem.
@mli Should I ignore the perl-test?
Oops, mistake. It is not in the `Operator` class. The interface should be in the `OperatorProperty` class.

Is the code available yet for Deep Compression? antinucleon mentioned that it is straightforward to implement, but the devil is in the details, and I suspect that only those with in-depth knowledge of caffe and deep networks can do this easily. Having the code would go a long way in making this reproducible and more widely accepted and used.

guess you need to update the submodule as well?
it's already fixed.

fusing forward while keeping backward is impossible due to many things. Only changing this won't help. You also have control_dep/backward infershape problems.

In general I don't think you can modify the forward graph after gradientpass (it is possible to modify the backward part of the graph after gradient pass, however). Also I don't see any reason to modify forward graph after gradient. You can do it before gradientpass is applied.
The failure on jenkins/pr-head is not due to this change

You can refer this issue:
I wanna train ResNet-50 based on my data  Issue #5404  dmlc/mxnet
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/5404

The model size is related to **the size of input image before first train** and network input user defined. 

For example, if you train a ResNet using 3\*229\*229-size input image, you will get a pretrained model with 3\*229\*229-size input. In addition, this's also related to the model itself, if the model does not have a full connection layer, then size of input image can be ignored.
